docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT four songs into her recent showcase set at Joe's Pub in Manhattan, Rosanne Cash turned to the guitarist John Leventhal, her husband and producer, and asked, ''Am I in tune?'' Then she laughed, strummed her acoustic guitar and added in mock triumph, ''To myself I am!'' The packed house of die-hard supporters (''I know 94 percent of the audience tonight -- oh, hi, Robert! -- 95 percent,'' she joked) chuckled sympathetically. Since releasing her debut album, ''Right or Wrong,'' in 1980, Ms. Cash, who is 47, has made compelling music out of her struggle to stay in tune with herself, to ignore expectations, both from others and from within. ''Rules for Travel,'' which came out on March 25, is her first collection of new songs in seven years, and it continues the intense process of self-exploration and discovery that has become her hallmark.

headline.main: The Cash Family Singers Finally Record Together

docs.abstract: Profile of singer Rosanne Cash, who has returned to recording after seven-year hiatus caused by throat polyp; trauma of losing voice and difficulties of relationship with father Johnny Cash discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the state cuts back on the amount of money it passes to cities and towns and their budgets get tighter, several municipalities are going where few tax collectors have gone before. They are sending property tax bills to nonprofit organizations. Encouraged by a State Supreme Court ruling in December that allowed Bridgeport to tax a homeless shelter, some communities have already begun rejecting the tax-exempt status of similar groups and others are looking into doing the same thing.
docs.abstract: Article on efforts by Connecticut cities and towns, strapped by tight state budget, to tax groups and organizations that were previously considered tax exempt; groups say they will be forced to cut services or close; photos (M)
docs.snippet: AS the state cuts back on the amount of money it passes to cities and towns and their budgets get tighter, several municipalities are going where few tax collectors have gone before. They are sending property tax bills to nonprofit organizations.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Theatrical wizardry bridged Beijing and New York on Thursday night when the Living Dance Studio presented ''Report on Body'' as part of the World Wide Works Series at Dance Theater Workshop. With choreography created by Wen Hui in collaboration with the performers, video designs by Wu Wenguang and a taped score by Wen Bin, the production by this Beijing-based modern-dance group evoked urban tensions and the problems of women in cities. Much of the choreography was based on the heightening of ordinary gestures, and the work's collagelike structure recalled the German dance-theater creations of Pina Bausch, one of Ms. Wen's many teachers in Europe and the United States.

headline.main: City Glamour and Squalor, Inspiring and Exploiting

docs.lead_paragraph: Troubled by signs that the battle against AIDS has stalled in the United States, federal health officials recommended today that pregnant women, intravenous drug users and anyone who has engaged in unsafe sex be routinely screened for the disease. Infants born to mothers who have not been tested for the virus that causes AIDS should also be checked, according to new guidelines announced by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: Some Routine AIDS Screening Is Advised

docs.abstract: Federal health officials, concerned that battle against AIDS has stalled in US, recommend routine screening of pregnant women, intravenous drug users and anyone who has engaged in unsafe sexual behavior; also calls for testing of infants whose mothers have not been tested; resurgence of AIDS among homosexual men and blacks noted (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A CRUEL circumstance, in the form of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack that scarred her neighborhood, scared away many of her neighbors and devastated her then-fledgling restaurant, Vine, has rendered Julie Menin a bit of a human phoenix. For her, the ashes of the tragedy are the foundation for an improved downtown. Ms. Menin, who lives and works at 25 Broad Street -- and is the only downtown resident on the 13-member jury that will adjudicate the ground zero memorial competition -- is a futurist, and hers is a one-track mind. ''This is where I live and work and where I've chosen to raise my child,'' she says, softly yet emphatically. ''While Sept. 11 made many things more difficult, it also opened up the possibility of fixing some of the problems we had prior to the tragedy when we were right on the cusp of becoming a 24/7 community.''

headline.main: Caring Intensively for Her Wounded Neighborhood

docs.abstract: Public Lives interview with Julie Menin on her work to resuscitate Lower Manhattan, where she lives in landmark building owned and renovated by her husband Bruce; photo; Menin, who founded organization Wall Street Rising, is only downtown resident on jury that will adjudicate ground zero memorial competition (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. What determines whether a navel is an innie or an outie? A. While there is not always a definitive explanation for the concave or convex shape of the navel, ''what causes it is clearly not the doctor,'' and it has nothing to do with how the umbilical cord is cut, said Dr. Richard A. Polin, director of the neonatal unit at Children's Hospital of New York-Presbyterian.
docs.abstract: Q & A column explains how umbilical cord come to be protruded rather than concave (S)
